coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
High-resolution, high-intensity photoionization studies were performed near the carbon and oxygen K-edges of gas-phase CO. At least 37 absorption lines were resolved at the carbon K-edge, and new information was obtained about the π*, Rydberg, and double-excitation resonances, including Rydberg states up to n=7 and vibrational transitions up to v′ = 3. Vibrational structure in oxygen is 1s−1π* and Rydberg states was resolved for the first time. The derived molecular structure parameters are consistent with the Z+1 approximation. High-resolution, high-intensity core-level photoabsorption promises new opportunities in vibrational state-to-state chemistry and surface science.

High-resolution, high-intensity core-level photoabsorption promises new opportunities in vibra- tional state-to-state chemistry and surface science. 1. IntroductIon Core-level excitation can provide unique insight into molecular structure and dynamics. An essential feature of this spectroscopy is the excitation of an electron from a highly localized initial orbital cen- tered on a single atom into a valence, Rydberg, or continuum orbital, sometimes accompanied by ad- ditional excitation in the system. The value of core- level spectroscopy is greatly enhanced by resolution at the vibrational level, allowing molecular struc- tural parameters to be derived from Franck Condon factors. Vibrational resolution is possible in small molecules based on carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen, in which the vibrational quantum of energy can exceed the natural linewidth of the Is core-hole state. Until recently, resolution at this level was achieved only with electron-energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS), which provided most of our detailed knowledge of near-edge structure [l-4] ~ . Photon-based excita- tion with highly monochromatic soft X-rays from an electron storage ring offers certain advantages. Most important is even higher resolution without the con- comitant loss of intensity evident in EELS. Consequently, the vibrational substates of the two-electron excita- tion show a strong 0-+0 transition and (slowly) de- creasing intensities for higher vibrations. In case of N2, on the other hand, the (is iv ') state has a larger equilibrium distance than the molecular ground state. For two-electron excitations, the equilibrium dis- tance is expected to increase even more. Both a de- crease in stability of the molecule and the excitation into various vibrational states will decrease the in- tensities of the individual peaks in the two-electron excitation which, as expected, appear with smaller intensities than in the case of CO. 8. Conclusions High-resolution, high-intensity photoionization spectra of carbon and oxygen K-edge excitation were analyzed to yield detailed structural parameters for C-l s-based 1h l e and 2h 2e states and O-l s-based 1h le states in CO. The results are consistent with, and confirm, the Z+ 1 approximation and the con- ventional picture of chemical bonding in CO. The high soft X-ray resolution and intensity available from plane-grating monochromators will facilitate more difficult weak-signal experiments. Among these are vibrational (state-to-state) photo-dissociation and molecular spectroscopy of adsorbed molecules on surfaces.
